base_hypothesis.title: Epigenetic-miRNA Synergy: A Novel Modality to Attenuate NF-κB Driven Inflammation in Rheumatoid Arthritis
base_hypothesis.statement: I hypothesize that in rheumatoid arthritis, targeted modulation of epigenetic changes impacting histone acetylation can alter the expression of key microRNAs which, by governing transcription factors involved in Th17 differentiation, lead to decreased IL17A/IL17F gene expression and thereby dampen oxidative-stress amplified cytokine signaling cascades, ultimately reducing NF-κB activation and inflammation.
base_hypothesis.summary: This hypothesis proposes that manipulating epigenetic modifications to adjust miRNA expression offers a novel approach to suppress IL-17 mediated inflammatory signaling cascades culminating in NF-κB inhibition in rheumatoid arthritis. It integrates epigenetic, miRNA, and transcription factor regulation to achieve therapeutic effects.

mechanism.pathway_description: Epigenetic modifications (specifically histone acetylation changes) modulate the expression of specific microRNAs. These microRNAs target and regulate transcription factors that control the expression of IL17A and IL17F genes. Reduced IL-17 production leads to decreased cytokine signaling cascades, which when compounded with attenuated oxidative stress-driven activation, results in lower NF-κB activity and reduced inflammation.

base_hypothesis.title: Combined Epigenetic and miRNA Modulation Reduces NF-κB Activation in Rheumatoid Arthritis
base_hypothesis.statement: We hypothesize that in rheumatoid arthritis, targeting epigenetic modifications (specifically, histone acetylation) to alter miRNA expression can modulate transcription factors driving IL-17 gene expression, thereby disrupting the IL-17 mediated cytokine cascade and attenuating oxidative stress-induced NF-κB activation to reduce inflammation.
base_hypothesis.summary: The hypothesis posits that coupling epigenetic modulators with miRNA-based therapeutics can dampen IL-17 pathway signaling and subsequent NF-κB activation in rheumatoid arthritis, offering a novel therapeutic strategy with measurable anti-inflammatory outcomes.

mechanism.pathway_description: Epigenetic modifications affecting histone acetylation alter the transcription of specific miRNAs, which target key transcription factors (e.g., STAT3, RORγt) involved in immune cell differentiation. This modulation influences IL17A and IL17F gene expression within the IL-17 pathways. The resulting dampening of IL-17 signaling reduces the activation of cytokine signaling cascades that, when amplified by oxidative stress, lead to NF-κB nuclear translocation and inflammatory gene expression.
mechanism.molecular_interactions: Epigenetic modifiers adjust chromatin structure to change miRNA transcription. The miRNAs bind to mRNAs encoding transcription factors, thereby impacting their translation and activity on IL-17 gene promoters. Reduced IL-17 levels then lead to lower cytokine production and diminished NF-κB activation.
mechanism.cellular_processes: Altered immune cell differentiation, modulation of cytokine production, reduction in oxidative stress-induced signaling, and decreased NF-κB mediated inflammatory responses.
